subsection.title: Maclaurin Series in k and k^{\prime}

para.sentence: Initial terms are given by \operatorname{sn}\left(z,k\right)=\sin z-\frac{k^{2}}{4}(z-\sin z\cos z)\cos z +O\left(k^{4}\right), \operatorname{cn}\left(z,k\right)=\cos z+\frac{k^{2}}{4}(z-\sin z\cos z)\sin z +O\left(k^{4}\right), \operatorname{dn}\left(z,k\right)=1-\frac{k^{2}}{2}{\sin^{2}}z+O\left(k^{4} \right), \operatorname{sn}\left(z,k\right)=\tanh z-\frac{{k^{\prime}}^{2}}{4}(z-\sinh z \cosh z){\operatorname{sech}^{2}}z+O\left({k^{\prime}}^{4}\right), \operatorname{cn}\left(z,k\right)=\operatorname{sech}z+\frac{{k^{\prime}}^{2}} {4}(z-\sinh z\cosh z)\tanh z\operatorname{sech}z+O\left({k^{\prime}}^{4}\right), \operatorname{dn}\left(z,k\right)=\operatorname{sech}z+\frac{{k^{\prime}}^{2}} {4}(z+\sinh z\cosh z)\tanh z\operatorname{sech}z+O\left({k^{\prime}}^{4}\right).
Further terms may be derived from the differential equations (22.13.13), (22.13.14), (22.13.15), or from the integral representations of the inverse functions in §22.15(ii).

The radius of convergence is the distance to the origin from thenearest pole in the complex k -plane in the case of (22.10.4)–(22.10.6), or complex k^{\prime} -plane in the case of (22.10.7)–(22.10.9);see §22.17.
